natural problem:
The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$
natural solution: The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$

Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real^3^3"
and a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix ([[a,1,b],[2,2,3],[c,5,d]])"
and h1 : "B = matrix ([[-5,e,-11],[f,-13,g],[2,h,4]])"
and h2 : "matrix_inv A = B"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real^3^3"
and a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "A = matrix ([[a,1,b],[2,2,3],[c,5,d]])"
and h1 : "B = matrix ([[-5,e,-11],[f,-13,g],[2,h,4]])"
and h2 : "matrix_inv A = B"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given two 3x3 matrices A and B, where A = [[a, 1, b], [2, 2, 3], [c, 5, d]] and B = [[-5, e, -11], [f, -13, g], [2, h, 4]]. If B is the inverse of A, find the sum of a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h. The final answer is 45.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
and M1 :: "real^3^3" and M2 :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M1 = (| (a,1,b), (2,2,3), (c,5,d) |)"
and h1 : "M2 = (| (-5,e,-11), (f,-13,g), (2,h,4) |)"
and h2 : "M1 ** M2 = mat 1"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
and M1 :: "real^3^3" and M2 :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M1 = (| (a,1,b), (2,2,3), (c,5,d) |)"
and h1 : "M2 = (| (-5,e,-11), (f,-13,g), (2,h,4) |)"
and h2 : "M1 ** M2 = mat 1"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider two 3x3 matrices, M1 and M2. M1 has rows (a, 1, b), (2, 2, 3), (c, 5, d) and M2 has rows (-5, e, -11), (f, -13, g), (2, h, 4). If the product of M1 and M2 is the 3x3 identity matrix, what is the sum of a, b, c, d, e, f, g, and h? The final answer is 45.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "matrix_inv (Matrix [[a, 1, b], [2, 2, 3], [c, 5, d]]) = Matrix [[-5, e, -11], [f, -13, g], [2, h, 4]]"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "matrix_inv (Matrix [[a, 1, b], [2, 2, 3], [c, 5, d]]) = Matrix [[-5, e, -11], [f, -13, g], [2, h, 4]]"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given that the inverse of a 3x3 matrix [[a, 1, b], [2, 2, 3], [c, 5, d]] is [[-5, e, -11], [f, -13, g], [2, h, 4]], find the sum of a, b, c, d, e, f, g and h. The final answer is 45.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "matrix_inv (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then a else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then b else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then c else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then d else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 2 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 3 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else 5)) = (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then -5 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then e else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -11 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then f else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -13 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then g else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then h else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 4 else 2))"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "matrix_inv (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then a else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then b else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then c else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then d else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then 2 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then 3 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then 1 else 5)) = (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i,j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then -5 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then e else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -11 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then f else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -13 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then g else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then h else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 4 else 2))"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix A, where the elements of the matrix are given by the following rules: 

- A[1,1] = a
- A[1,3] = b
- A[3,1] = c
- A[3,3] = d
- A[2,2] = 2
- A[2,3] = 3
- A[1,2] = 1
- All other elements are 5

The inverse of this matrix is another 3x3 matrix B, where the elements are given by the following rules:

- B[1,1] = -5
- B[1,2] = e
- B[1,3] = -11
- B[2,1] = f
- B[2,2] = -13
- B[2,3] = g
- B[3,2] = h
- B[3,3] = 4
- All other elements are 2

Find the values of a, b, c, d, e, f, g and h such that the sum a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h equals 45.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "mat_inv (mat_of_rows_list [[a,1,b],[2,2,3],[c,5,d]]) = mat_of_rows_list [[-5,e,-11],[f,-13,g],[2,h,4]]"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "mat_inv (mat_of_rows_list [[a,1,b],[2,2,3],[c,5,d]]) = mat_of_rows_list [[-5,e,-11],[f,-13,g],[2,h,4]]"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If the inverse of the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{bmatrix}$ is the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{bmatrix}$, find the sum of all the variables ($a$ through $h$). The final answer is 45.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "mat_inv (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then a else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then b else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then c else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then d else 0)) = 
                Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then -5 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then e else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -11 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then f else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -13 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then g else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then h else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 4 else 0)"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "mat_inv (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then a else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then b else if i = 3 \<and> j = 1 then c else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then d else 0)) = 
                Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 1 \<and> j = 1 then -5 else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then e else if i = 1 \<and> j = 3 then -11 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then f else if i = 2 \<and> j = 2 then -13 else if i = 2 \<and> j = 3 then g else if i = 3 \<and> j = 2 then h else if i = 3 \<and> j = 3 then 4 else 0)"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem:
The problem is as follows: 

You have a 3x3 matrix where the elements at positions (1,1), (1,3), (3,1), and (3,3) are a, b, c, and d respectively. The rest of the elements in the matrix are 0. 

The inverse of this matrix is another 3x3 matrix where the elements at positions (1,1), (1,2), (1,3), (2,1), (2,2), (2,3), (3,2), and (3,3) are -5, e, -11, f, -13, g, h, and 4 respectively. The rest of the elements in this matrix are also 0.

The problem is to find the values of a, b, c, d, e, f, g, and h such that the sum of these eight variables is equal to 45.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "mat_inv (list_of_list_to_matrix [[a, 1, b], [2, 2, 3], [c, 5, d]]) =
               list_of_list_to_matrix [[-5, e, -11], [f, -13, g], [2, h, 4]]"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "mat_inv (list_of_list_to_matrix [[a, 1, b], [2, 2, 3], [c, 5, d]]) =
               list_of_list_to_matrix [[-5, e, -11], [f, -13, g], [2, h, 4]]"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Suppose that the inverse of the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{bmatrix}$ is equal to the matrix $\begin{bmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{bmatrix}$. What is the sum of the variables $a, b, c, d, e, f, g$, and $h$? The final answer is $45$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[a,1,b], [2,2,3], [c,5,d]])"
and h1 : "B = matrix([[-5,e,-11], [f,-13,g], [2,h,4]])"
and h2 : "A ** B = mat 1"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "A = matrix([[a,1,b], [2,2,3], [c,5,d]])"
and h1 : "B = matrix([[-5,e,-11], [f,-13,g], [2,h,4]])"
and h2 : "A ** B = mat 1"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Given two 3x3 matrices $A$ and $B$ defined as follows:

$A = \begin{bmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{bmatrix}$ 

and 

$B = \begin{bmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{bmatrix}$

If the product of $A$ and $B$ is the 3x3 identity matrix, what is the sum of the variables $a, b, c, d, e, f, g,$ and $h$? The final answer is 45.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real and M N :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[a,1,b], [2,2,3], [c,5,d]])"
and h1 : "N = matrix([[-5,e,-11], [f,-13,g], [2,h,4]])"
and h2 : "M ** N = 1\<^sub>m 3"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d e f g h :: real and M N :: "real^3^3"
assumes h0 : "M = matrix([[a,1,b], [2,2,3], [c,5,d]])"
and h1 : "N = matrix([[-5,e,-11], [f,-13,g], [2,h,4]])"
and h2 : "M ** N = 1\<^sub>m 3"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given two 3x3 matrices, M and N, where M is formed by the real numbers a, 1, b, 2, 2, 3, c, 5, d and N is formed by the real numbers -5, e, -11, f, -13, g, 2, h, 4. If the product of M and N equals the 3x3 identity matrix, find the sum of all the variables (a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h). The final answer is 45.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes A B :: "real^3^3" and a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "A = ((a,1,b), (2,2,3), (c,5,d))"
and h1 : "B = ((-5,e,-11), (f,-13,g), (2,h,4))"
and h2 : "matrix_inv A = B"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The matrices
\[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \quad \text{and} \quad \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix}\]are inverses.  Find $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h.$ The final Answer is 45
 ### Proof
 The product of the matrices is \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ f & -13 & g \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + f + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + g + 4b \\ -10 + 2f + 6 & 2e - 26 + 3h & -22 + 2g + 12 \\ -5c + 5f + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 5g + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]We have that $-10 + 2f + 6 = -22 + 2g + 12 = 0,$ so $f = 2$ and $g = 5.$
 Then \[\begin{pmatrix} a & 1 & b \\ 2 & 2 & 3 \\ c & 5 & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} -5 & e & -11 \\ 2 & -13 & 5 \\ 2 & h & 4 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} -5a + 2 + 2b & ae - 13 + bh & -11a + 5 + 4b \\ 0 & 2e - 26 + 3h & 0 \\ -5c + 10 + 2d & ce - 65 + dh & -11c + 25 + 4d \end{pmatrix}.\]This gives us $-5a + 2 + 2b = 1,$ $-11a + 5 + 4b = 0,$ $-5c + 10 + 2d = 0,$ and $-11c + 25 + 4d = 1.$  Solving these equations, we find $a = 3,$ $b = 7,$ $c = 4,$ and $d = 5.$
 Hence, $3e - 13 + 7h = 0,$ $2e - 26 + 3h = 1,$ and $4e - 65 + 5h = 0.$  Solving, we find $e = 30$ and $h = -11.$
 Therefore, $a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 3 + 7 + 4 + 5 + 30 + 2 + 5 + (-11) = \boxed{45}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes A B :: "real^3^3" and a b c d e f g h :: real
assumes h0 : "A = ((a,1,b), (2,2,3), (c,5,d))"
and h1 : "B = ((-5,e,-11), (f,-13,g), (2,h,4))"
and h2 : "matrix_inv A = B"
shows  "a + b + c + d + e + f + g + h = 45"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given two 3x3 matrices A and B, where A is defined as ((a,1,b), (2,2,3), (c,5,d)) and B is defined as ((-5,e,-11), (f,-13,g), (2,h,4)). If B is the inverse of A, find the sum of all the variables a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h. The final answer is 45.
